sub_topic: Population growth models using differential equations
message_1: A population of rabbits on an island grows according to the logistic growth model. The carrying capacity of the island is 1000 rabbits and the initial population is 100. If the growth rate parameter is 0.05 per year, find the population after 10 years.
message_2:
The logistic growth model is given by the formula:

P(t) = K / (1 + (K - P0) / P0 * e^(-r*t))

where P(t) is the population at time t, K is the carrying capacity, P0 is the initial population, r is the growth rate parameter, and e is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.71828).

In this case, K = 1000 rabbits, P0 = 100 rabbits, r = 0.05 per year, and we want to find the population after 10 years, so t = 10.

Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

P(10) = 1000 / (1 + (1000 - 100) / 100 * e^(-0.05*10))

P(10) = 1000 / (1 + 900 / 100 * e^(-0.5))

P(10) = 1000 / (1 + 9 * e^(-0.5))

Now, we can calculate the value of e^(-0.5) and then the entire expression:

e^(-0.5) ≈ 0.60653

P(10) = 1000 / (1 + 9 * 0.60653)

P(10) = 1000 / (1 + 5.45877)

P(10) = 1000 / 6.45877

P(10) ≈ 154.79

So, after 10 years, the population of rabbits on the island will be approximately 155 rabbits.
